questions.text: A 38-year-old woman undergoes hemithyroidectomy for treatment of localized, well- differentiated papillary thyroid carcinoma. The lesion is removed with clear margins. However, during the surgery, a structure lying directly adjacent to the superior thyroid artery at the upper pole of the thyroid lobe is damaged. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Voice pitch limitation

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of insomnia. She frequently experiences leg discomfort when trying to fall asleep that is relieved temporarily by movement. Her husband tells her that she frequently flexes her ankles upward when she sleeps. She appears fatigued and anxious. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies including a complete blood count and iron studies are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Ropinirole

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Two weeks ago, he was treated in the emergency department for head trauma after being hit by a bicycle while crossing the street. Neurological examination reveals decreased taste sensation of anterior two third of the tongue. This cranial nerve damaged is also responsible for which of the following actions?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Eyelid closure

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate born at 28 weeks of gestation had developed respiratory distress syndrome at birth. You want to screen for retinopathy of prematurity. How many weeks from now would you schedule the screening?
questions.solution: Ans. B) 2 weeks

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician for worsening restlessness over the past several days. Three weeks ago, he was started on trifluoperazine for the treatment of schizophrenia. He reports that, since then, he has often felt compelled to pace around his house and is unable to sit or stand still. He is switched to an alternative antipsychotic medication. Four weeks later, the patient reports improvement of his symptoms but says that he has developed increased drowsiness, blurred vision, and dry mouth. The patient was most likely switched to which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chlorpromazine

 

This patient initially developed akathisia (a form of extrapyramidal symptom characterized by restlessness and inability to sit still) after being started on trifluoperazine, a high-potency typical antipsychotic. To manage this, he was switched to another drug. After the switch, he developed anticholinergic side effects such as sedation, blurred vision, and dry mouth, which are characteristic of low-potency typical antipsychotics like chlorpromazine and thioridazine. Hence, chlorpromazine is the most likely agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haloperidol: This is a high-potency typical antipsychotic, similar to trifluoperazine. It carries a high risk of extrapyramidal side effects (akathisia, dystonia, parkinsonism, tardive dyskinesia), not sedation and anticholinergic symptoms.

 

Option C. Trimipramine: This is a tricyclic antidepressant, not an antipsychotic. It is not used for schizophrenia and would not be the correct substitution for trifluoperazine.

 

Option D. Aripiprazole: This is an atypical antipsychotic with partial dopamine agonist activity. It has fewer extrapyramidal side effects but does not cause significant anticholinergic symptoms such as sedation and blurred vision.

choices.text: Basal turn of the cochlea

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-year history of progressive hearing loss. His hearing is worse in crowded rooms, and he has noticed that he has more difficulty understanding women than men. A Rinne test shows air conduction is greater than bone conduction bilaterally. This condition is most likely associated with damage closest to which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Basal turn of the cochlea

questions.text: After the administration of phenylephrine, the depicted images reveal an observed alteration. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Nodular episcleritis

questions.text: A 41-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a suicide attempt. His wife found him on the bathroom floor with an empty bottle of medication next to him. He has a history of major depressive disorder. His only medication is nortriptyline. His pulse is 127/min and blood pressure is 90/61 mmHg. Examination shows dilated pupils and dry skin. The abdomen is distended and there is dullness on percussion in the suprapubic region. An ECG shows tachycardia and a QRS complex width of 130 ms. In addition to intravenous fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sodium bicarbonate

 

This patient presents with an overdose of a tricyclic antidepressant (nortriptyline). TCAs in overdose cause anticholinergic toxicity (dilated pupils, dry skin, urinary retention, ileus), cardiac toxicity (tachycardia, hypotension, conduction delays such as prolonged QRS, ventricular arrhythmias), and CNS effects (seizures, delirium). The most dangerous feature is cardiac toxicity due to blockade of fast sodium channels in the cardiac myocytes, which manifests as a widened QRS complex. Intravenous sodium bicarbonate is the treatment of choice because it alleviates sodium channel blockade and reduces the risk of fatal arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic used for bradycardia or AV block. It would worsen the existing anticholinergic effects and is not useful in TCA toxicity.

 

Option B. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used to reverse opioid-induced respiratory and CNS depression. TCAs are not opioids, so naloxone has no role here.

 

Option C. Glucagon: Glucagon is used in beta-blocker overdose because it increases intracellular cyclic AMP independent of beta-adrenergic receptors. It does not help in TCA poisoning.

choices.text: Acute stress disorder
Major depressive disorder
Post-traumatic stress disorder
Major depressive disorder with peripartum onset

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty sleeping. She is afraid of falling asleep and gets up earlier than desired. Four months ago, she was the driver in a car accident that resulted in the death of her unborn child. She has vivid nightmares of the event and reports that she frequently re-experiences the accident. She blames herself for the death of her child, has stopped working as an accountant, avoids driving in cars, and has withdrawn from her parents and close friends. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Post-traumatic stress disorder

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-day history of intermittent dizziness and double vision. She reports double vision whenever she looks to the left. Last summer, she had an episode of weakness in her left leg that resolved spontaneously. Ophthalmologic examination shows weak adduction of the right eye on left lateral gaze. Attempted left lateral gaze results in horizontal nystagmus of the left eye. Convergence testing is normal. This patient most likely has a lesion in which of the following labeled areas of the schematic overview of a transverse section of the midbrain?
questions.solution: Ans. B) C

choices.text: Cerumen impaction on the right
Otosclerosis on the left
Cochlear ischemia on the right
Acoustic neuroma on the left

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of hearing loss. To test her hearing, the physician performs two tests. First, a vibrating tuning fork is held against the mastoid bone of the patient and then near her ear, to which the patient responds she hears the sound better on both sides when the tuning fork is held near her ear. Next, the physician holds the tuning fork against the bridge of her forehead, to which the patient responds she hears the sound better on the right side than the left. The patient's examination findings are most consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Acoustic neuroma on the left

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of right-sided facial weakness and sound intolerance. Three days ago, he hit the right side of his head in a motor vehicle collision. He neither lost consciousness nor sought medical attention. Sensation over the face is not impaired. Impedance audiometry shows an absence of the acoustic reflex in the right ear. Which of the following muscles is most likely paralyzed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stylohyoid

 

The muscle most likely paralyzed in this patient is the stylohyoid. This is because the facial nerve (CN VII) innervates the muscles of facial expression and the stylohyoid, as well as the stapedius muscle, which is involved in the acoustic reflex. Facial nerve palsy leads to facial weakness and loss of the acoustic reflex, with normal facial sensation and preserved trigeminal (CN V) functions. The other muscles mentioned are not supplied by the facial nerve and would not be affected in this setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tensor tympani: Supplied by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), not the facial nerve. Paralysis would not result from facial nerve injury.

 

Option B. Posterior cricoarytenoid: This is a laryngeal muscle innervated by the recurrent laryngeal nerve (a branch of vagus, CN X), unrelated to facial nerve injury.

 

Option C. Stylopharyngeus: Supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), not the facial nerve and its function is to facilitate bolus of food- movement down the Pharynx.

questions.text: Identify the syndrome:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Duane's retraction syndrome type 1

 

The clinical image shows the typical findings of Duane's retraction syndrome type 1:

 

  • There is marked limitation of abduction (outward movement) of the affected eye.
  • Adduction (movement towards the nose) is relatively preserved, but there is narrowing of the palpebral fissure and retraction of the globe on attempted adduction.
  • These findings are most consistent with Duane's retraction syndrome type 1, which is the most common subtype and is characterized by limited abduction, retraction of the globe, and narrowing of the eyelid opening on adduction.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her father because he has been worried about his daughter's strange behavior for the past 2 years. She does not have any friends, spends most of her time alone in her room, and does not feel comfortable around other people. She usually wears long cloaks and large, unusual hats. She wears her shoes to bed because she sleepwalks and claims "nargles" will try to steal them otherwise. Her father is concerned about her going to college because she was bullied in high school. At the end of last year, her father found her putting up posters around the school asking for her possessions to be returned, as the other students had been hiding them. The daughter seemed unconcerned though, saying that "it's all in good fun." On mental status examination, she seems dreamy and avoids eye contact, but doesn't appear embarrassed about being addressed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Schizotypal personality disorder

choices.text: ACTH low, Aldosterone low, Cortisol low
ACTH low, Aldosterone high, Cortisol low
ACTH high, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low
ACTH low, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low

questions.text: Two days after vaginal delivery of a healthy newborn at term, a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, is unable to breastfeed. Her labor was complicated by antepartum hemorrhage and she received two units of packed red blood cells. Her pulse is 99/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following sets of serum findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ACTH low, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low

 

This patient presents with inability to breastfeed two days postpartum, hypotension, and a history of significant antepartum hemorrhage with blood transfusions, suggesting postpartum hypopituitarism (Sheehan syndrome).

 

In Sheehan syndrome, ischemic necrosis of the pituitary leads to decreased secretion of anterior pituitary hormones, including ACTH, resulting in secondary adrenal insufficiency with low cortisol levels. Aldosterone secretion is typically preserved because it is regulated mainly by the renin-angiotensin system, not ACTH.

 

Therefore, the most likely serum findings are: ACTH low, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ACTH low, Aldosterone low, Cortisol low: Aldosterone is usually normal because it is regulated independently of ACTH.

 

Option B. ACTH low, Aldosterone high, Cortisol low: Aldosterone is unlikely to be high in this context.

 

Option C. ACTH high, Aldosterone normal, Cortisol low: ACTH would be low due to pituitary failure, not high.

choices.text: Hyperesthesia of the left ear lobe
Impaired taste of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue
Flushing of the right cheek while eating
Inability to wrinkle the left side of the forehead

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of increasing swelling in his left cheek and recurrent oral ulcers for 1 year. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Examination shows firm, nontender swelling above the angle of jaw. USG guided biopsy shows adenoid cystic carcinoma. A left sided total parotidectomy is performed. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Inability to wrinkle the left side of the forehead

questions.text: Two days after undergoing uncomplicated total knee replacement, a 55-year-old man develops increasing anxiety, agitation, hand tremor, and nausea. He told the nurse he saw a bear in his room. His pain has been controlled with intravenous morphine. He has a history of advanced liver disease. He drinks 7 cans of beer daily. He is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 146/92 mm Hg. Administration of which of the following drugs is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Lorazepam

questions.text: According to World Health Organization (WHO), blindness is defined as:
questions.solution: Ans. A) VA < 3/60

questions.text: Six days after undergoing surgical repair of a hip fracture, a previously healthy 79-year-old woman is agitated and confused. She is unarousable during the day, but then is awake and impulsive during the night, requiring frequent reorientation. Her husband says that she usually drinks one to two glasses of wine weekly. Her only current medication is oxycodone for pain. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is distressed and oriented to person but not to place or time. Neurologic examination shows inattentiveness but no focal deficits. Urine dipstick is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her current condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Delirium

questions.text: An investigator is developing a drug that selectively inhibits the retrograde axonal transport of rabies virus towards the central nervous system. To achieve this effect, this drug must target which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Dynein

choices.text: Silver nitrate exposure

questions.text: A 15-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician for evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 3 days. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received  irregular prenatal care during the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Examination of the newborn shows watery discharge in both eyes and mild swelling. Which of the following is the most  likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Chlamydia trachomatis

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of concerns about her behavior. She worries excessively about her weight and body image and has frequent diarrhea. She is 170cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 63.5 kg (140 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. She appears anxious but well. Physical examination shows calluses on the knuckles of her right hand. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Parotid gland swelling

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the therapist for weekly psychotherapy. She was diagnosed with major depressive disorder and anxiety after her divorce 1 year ago. During last week's appointment, she spoke about her ex-husband's timidity and lack of advancement at work; despite her urging, he never asked for a raise. Today, when the therapist asks how she is doing, she replies, "If there's something you want to know, have the courage to ask me! I have no respect for a man who won't speak his mind!" The patient's behavior can be best described as an instance of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transference

 

Transference refers to the unconscious redirection of feelings and attitudes from a significant person in ones past onto another person in the present, often the therapist. In this case, the patient projects her unresolved anger and frustration toward her ex-husband onto the therapist, treating him as though he shares her ex-husbands perceived weaknesses. This is a classic example of transference in psychotherapy, where past relational dynamics influence current therapeutic interactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Displacement: This involves redirecting emotions from a threatening target to a safer one (e.g., yelling at children after being scolded by a boss), not applicable here as its a symbolic repetition of past dynamics, not redirection.

 

Option C. Projection: Attributing ones own unacceptable feelings or impulses to others (e.g., a liar accusing others of dishonesty); the patient is not attributing her own traits but reacting to perceived traits of her ex.

 

Option D. Passive aggression: Indirectly expressing hostility through procrastination, stubbornness, or sarcasm; her statement here is direct and emotionally charged, not passive or indirect.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of multiple episodes of bilious vomiting. She is diagnosed with intestinal malrotation and volvulus and undergoes emergency laparotomy. During surgery, a 3 x 3 cm cystic mass is excised from behind the umbilicus. Microscopic examination of the mass shows mature nonciliated columnar epithelium with some goblet cells lining the inner cyst wall. Dilation of which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's mass?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Vitelline duct

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her neighbors 30 minutes after they found her unconscious in her yard. Her neighbors report that she has been spending more time at home by herself because she recently lost her job. On arrival, she is unable to provide a history. Her pulse is 76/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Examination shows significant weakness of the left upper and lower extremities. She is unable to plantarflex the ankle while supine. She is able to stand on her toes. Her gait is unsteady. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ and symmetric. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Conversion disorder

questions.text: Identify the BNS for Perjury:
questions.solution: Ans. A) 227

choices.text: Loss of taste in the posterior third of the right half of the tongue
Flattening of the right nasolabial fold
Decreased lacrimation of the left eye
Hyperacusis of left ear

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of disorientation and slurred speech. He has a 10-year history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His blood pressure is 210/110 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min. Once the patient is stabilized, an MRI of the brain is performed, which shows an infarct of the left precentral gyrus involving the region that supplies the facial nerve. Given the MRI findings, which of the following neurological findings would most be expected?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Flattening of the right nasolabial fold

questions.text: 41-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 7-month history of sleep disturbances and restlessness. He has difficulty falling asleep and lies awake worrying about his family, the next day's meetings, and finances. Eight months ago, he started a new job as a product manager. He can no longer concentrate on his tasks at work. He feels tense most days and avoids socializing with his friends. He has a history of drinking alcohol excessively during his early 20s, but he has not consumed alcohol for the past 10 years. He appears anxious. The patient states that he is concerned about the side effects of psychiatric medications. He has struggled intermittently with erectile dysfunction in the past and would like a medication that will not further aggravate his difficulties. Treatment with which of the following drugs is most appropriate in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Mirtazapine

choices.text: Family history of completed suicide

questions.text: A 29-year-old man with post-traumatic stress disorder is admitted to the hospital following an intentional opioid overdose. He is a soldier who returned from a deployment in Afghanistan 3 months ago. He is divorced and lives alone. His mother died by suicide when he was 8 years of age. He states that he intended to end his life as painlessly as possible and has also contemplated using his service firearm to end his life. He does not smoke or drink alcohol but uses medical marijuana daily. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for suicide in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Attempted drug overdose

questions.text: The World Health Organization suggests the use of a new rapid diagnostic test for the diagnosis of malaria in resource-limited settings. The new test has a sensitivity of 70% and a specificity of 90% compared to the gold standard test (blood smear). The validity of the new test is evaluated at a satellite health center by testing 200 patients with a positive blood smear and 150 patients with a negative blood smear. How many of the tested individuals are expected to have a false negative result?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 60

 

False negatives occur among those who truly have malaria (blood-smear positive) and are missed by the test. 

 

Sensitivity = 70% means the test correctly identifies 70% of true positives and misses 30%.

 

Remember the formulae:

 

Here,

 

For 200 true positives, 30% 200 = 60 false negatives. So 60 individuals with positive blood smears will test negative on the rapid test.

questions.text: 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the warden of his hostel for strange behavior. He was found locked out of his room, where the patient admitted to attending a party. The patient appears anxious. His pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 142/85 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and bilateral conjunctival injection. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Impaired reaction time

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because she is concerned about her son's behavior. She reports that he has been wearing her dresses at home and asks to be called Lilly. He also stopped going to swim class because he "doesn't feel comfortable in swim trunks." Since starting puberty about a year ago, he has not had any friends and the teachers report he is consistently being bullied at school. She also mentions that as a child her son never enjoyed playing with "typical boy toys like cars" and instead preferred dressing up dolls. Physical examination shows normal male external genitalia. There is scarce coarse, dark axillary and pubic hair. Upon questioning, the patient reports that he would rather be a girl. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gender dysphoria

 

This adolescent meets the criteria for gender dysphoria, which refers to a marked incongruence between ones experienced or expressed gender and assigned biological sex, causing clinically significant distress or functional impairment.

 

Here, the boy identifies as female ("asks to be called Lilly," prefers female clothing), feels discomfort with male secondary sexual characteristics (avoiding swim trunks), and experiences social distress (bullying, isolation). These features go beyond mere gender nonconformity and fulfill diagnostic criteria for gender dysphoria.

 

Key Diagnostic Features of Gender Dysphoria:

 

  • Persistent incongruence between experienced gender and assigned sex
  • Strong desire to be or be treated as another gender
  • Discomfort with ones sexual anatomy or secondary sex traits
  • Clinically significant distress or functional impairment in social or academic areas
  • Duration: 6 months

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gender nonconformity: Refers to behavior or interests that do not match cultural norms for ones assigned sex (e.g., a boy liking dolls or dressing up). It is not a disorder unless associated with significant distress or desire to be another gender, which this case clearly shows.

 

Option B. Sexual aversion: Involves extreme fear or disgust toward sexual activity or sexual contact; unrelated to gender identity or expression.

 

Option C. Transvestic disorder: Characterized by sexual arousal from cross-dressing in heterosexual men; this patients cross-dressing is identity-based, not sexual, and is accompanied by gender incongruence rather than erotic gratification.

choices.text: Sensory deficit of the dorsal foot

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He reports right hip pain and numbness along the right thigh. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch over a small area of the medial thigh. X-rays of the pelvis show a displaced pelvic ring fracture. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Impaired adduction of hip

 

Pelvic ring fractures commonly injure the obturator nerve, which supplies the hip adductors (e.g., adductor longus, brevis, magnus) and sensory supply to the medial thigh. Thus, physical findings include impaired hip adduction and decreased sensation over the medial thigh, as described. Obturator nerve injury is classic in pelvic trauma with these neurological findings, often confirmed by clinical and electrophysiological tests.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensory deficit of the dorsal foot: Injury to nerves supplying the dorsal foot (e.g., superficial peroneal nerve) more commonly occurs with fibular neck fractures, not pelvic ring injuries.

 

Option B. Impaired hip extension: Hip extension is supplied by the gluteal nerves and hamstrings, which are less likely to be affected by a pelvic ring fracture, unless the sciatic nerve is specifically injured.

 

Option C. Impaired dorsiflexion of the foot: Dorsiflexion is controlled by the deep peroneal nerve from L4-L5, involved with lumbosacral plexus injuries, not classically obturator nerve lesions in pelvic fractures

questions.text: A 5-day post-operative patient on intravenous fluids presents with angular stomatitis and following appearance of cornea. Which of the following TCA cycle enzymes is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Succinate dehydrogenase

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors and moving towards the cortex?

  1. Auditory Cortex
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Cochlear Nucleus
  4. Lateral leminiscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Olivary complex
  7. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution: Ans. C. 2-3-6-4-5-7-1

questions.text: A 35-year-old male, diagnosed with squint presented to the ophthalmology department for regular check-up. On examination, marked muscle was found affected. At which level does the nerve supply for the marked structure arise?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Red nucleus

choices.text: Right monocular blindness
Hemianopia with macular sparing

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of diminished vision for several months. Twenty-eight years ago, she was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus, which has been well controlled with hydroxychloroquine. Fundoscopic examination shows concentric rings of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation surrounding the fovea bilaterally. Visual field examination of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Paracentral scotoma

choices.text: Failed descent of a pharyngeal pouch structure
Failed neural crest migration into a pharyngeal arch
Inadequate fusion of the mandibular prominences
Incomplete obliteration of a pharyngeal groove

questions.text: 1-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for mass in the neck. The parents noticed a small area of nontender swelling in the neck a month ago. Over the last few days, it has enlarged and become painful, and the patient has a fever. Examination shows a mobile, tender, fluctuant, and warm mass approximately 2 cm in diameter that is located at the right mandibular angle. There is purulent drainage from the skin surface just anterior to the right sternocleidomastoid muscle. This patient's clinical findings are most likely due to which of the following embryologic processes?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Incomplete obliteration of a pharyngeal groove

choices.text: True positive fistula test indicates perilymph fistula
False positive fistula test indicates congenital syphilis
True negative fistula test indicates late stages of Menieres disease
False negative fistula test indicates dead labyrinth

questions.text: Identify the false statement from the following:
questions.solution: Ans. C) True negative fistula test indicates late stages of Menieres disease

choices.text: Atrialization of the right ventricle

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of nausea and fatigue. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago. She has a history of bipolar disorder controlled by a drug known to sometimes cause hypothyroidism and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. A urine pregnancy test is positive. An ultrasound of the pelvis shows a viable intrauterine pregnancy. The fetus is most likely at increased risk for which of the following anomalies?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Atrialization of the right ventricle

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is seen in the clinic for a follow-up appointment after his recent myocardial infarction. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. Despite previous advice to modify his lifestyle, he continues to smoke and consume a diet high in saturated fats. When discussing his lifestyle choices, he states, "I know smoking isn't great, but I've seen plenty of people live long lives even though they smoke. Plus, I only eat fast food because it's the only thing that fits into my busy schedule." Which of the following defence mechanisms is the patient primarily using?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Rationalization

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair of questionnaires with the disorders:
questions.solution: Ans. B. STOP-BANG- Opioid abuse

questions.text: Local anesthesia used in cataract surgery is:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Lignocaine 2%

questions.text: A previously healthy 51-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of confusion for 2 hours. His wife reports that he fell and hit his head while changing a ceiling light the previous evening. On arrival, he is unconscious. His temperature is 37.1C (98.8F), pulse is 54/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 198/106 mm Hg. The right pupil is dilated and fixed; the left pupil is round and reactive to light. There is extension of the extremities to painful stimuli. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A mannitol infusion is begun. A noncontrast CT scan of the brain shows herniation of the right medial temporal lobe. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right-sided hemiplegia

 

This patient has uncal (transtentorial) herniation due to head trauma temporal lobe compresses against tentorium cerebelli.

 

Key features:

 

  • Dilated, fixed ipsilateral pupil compression of ipsilateral CN III (oculomotor nerve).
  • Hemiplegia on the same side (ipsilateral hemiplegia) due to compression of contralateral cerebral peduncle against tentorium (Kernohans notch phenomenon false localizing sign).
  • Cushings triad seen here: hypertension + bradycardia + irregular breathing.
  • Decerebrate posturing (extension to pain) suggests midbrain/upper pons involvement.

 

Thus, the most likely finding is right-sided hemiplegia (same side as the dilated pupil).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bilateral spasticity: Suggests diffuse upper motor neuron lesions (eg, advanced ALS, spinal cord injury), not acute herniation.

 

Option C. Bilateral lower limb paralysis: More typical of anterior cerebral artery infarction, not uncal herniation.

 

Option D. Right eye esotropia and elevation: Seen in CN VI (abducens) palsy, but here the oculomotor nerve is affected causing down & out eye with ptosis and mydriasis, not esotropia.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman with Alzheimer dementia is brought to the OPD for evaluation of new-onset drooling. The patient lives in a nursing home and the staff noticed that she has been having liquid drip out of the right side of her mouth when they feed her. She has also been very tearful over the past 2 weeks, particularly at night when she wakes up crying and clutching her ear. The patient has type 2 diabetes mellites that requires insulin and multiple medications. Her last hemoglobin A1c was 8.5%. Temperature is 380C (100.4 F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination of the right ear canal shows granulation tissue with a surrounding white drainage in the floor of the canal. The tympanic membrane is clear and mobile to pneumatic otoscopy. There is facial asymmetry with some downward deviation of the right corner of the mouth. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism for this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa

questions.text:
A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. The risk of which of the following is increased in the newborn?

  1. Low APGAR score.
  2. ADHD.
  3. Persistent pulmonary hypertension.
  4. Delayed developmental milestones.

ADHD - attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
questions.solution: Ans. B. 1,2,3,4

questions.text: A mother brings her 8-year-old boy with complaints of bedwetting. On asking history, she informs that he does this about 3 to 4 times per week. On further evaluation, he has a normal urine stream, daytime urine continence, and no history of UTIs. His physical examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Use of enuresis alarm

 

This child has primary nocturnal enuresis (bedwetting in a child 5 years with no underlying medical cause). He has normal daytime continence, normal urinary stream, and no history suggesting infection or structural abnormality. After ruling out organic causes, the most effective first-line management is behavioral therapy with enuresis alarm. These alarms condition the child to wake up at the sensation of a full bladder, and they have the highest long-term success rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ultrasound of abdomen: Indicated if there are signs of structural urinary tract disease, recurrent UTIs, abnormal urinary stream, or daytime incontinence. Since the child has normal examination and no such history, ultrasound is unnecessary.

 

Option B. Reassurance: While reassurance may be appropriate in very young children (<5 years) or when frequency is rare, this boy is 8 years old and wets the bed 34 times a week, making active intervention necessary.

 

Option D. Desmopressin acetate: This can be used if enuresis alarm fails, or when rapid control is needed (eg, sleepovers, camps). However, it has a higher relapse rate compared to alarm therapy, so it is not the first-line choice for long-term management.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair
questions.solution: Ans. D) Ethionamide- Colour vision changes

choices.text: The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the Scala tympani
Cochleostomy is then performed anteroinferior to the round window membrane to a diameter of 1.0 - 1.6 mm
Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss is an absolute contraindication
Facial recess approach is most commonly used

questions.text: All of the following are true about cochlear implant except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss is an absolute contraindication.

questions.text: 28-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to persistent nasal congestion and stuffiness. The patient has a constant sensation of dripping in the back of her throat and states that food has tasted bland to her recently. A year ago, she came to the emergency department due to severe wheezing after taking naproxen for menstrual cramping. Family history is significant for asthma in her sister. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patients current symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Nasal polyposis

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion 

 

The given tympanogram is Type B (flat curve), indicating otitis media with effusion (OME).

 

Key points in the case:

 

  • Child = 6 years old
  • Recurrent URTI
  • Poor growth, high-arched palate (suggesting possible adenoid hypertrophy or cleft palate association)
  • Hearing impairment
  • Tympanogram = Type B (effusion)

 

Management:

 

  • Grommet insertion (ventilation tube) is the standard treatment for persistent OME causing hearing loss.
  • In a 6-year-old child with recurrent URTIs and possible adenoid hypertrophy, the definitive management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion, because:
    • Adenoid hypertrophy blocks eustachian tube recurrent OME.
    • Removing adenoids + ventilation tube prevents recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grommet insertion: Effective for effusion, but without adenoidectomy, recurrence is high due to persistent adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion:

 

  • Myringotomy alone is only for drainage; grommet is placed afterward.
  • Still incomplete without addressing the adenoids in this age group with URTI history.

 

Option D. Myringotomy: Alone is insufficient; effusion reaccumulates within days.

choices.text: Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to a hospital with a 3-week history of muffled hearing and a sensation of fullness in the right ear. Examination is shown below.  The patient denies any recent upper respiratory infections or allergies. In managing his condition, which procedure is most appropriate to relieve his symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Myringotomy with tympanostomy tube insertion

The patient developed a mild cough and sore throat yesterday, his parents gave him acetaminophen, which improved his throat pain. However, this morning the patient had difficulty breathing and was sitting in bed and leaning forward refusing to lie down.  Oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. The patient appears anxious, is drooling, and has inspiratory stridor. The uvula is midline, and there is no oropharyngeal or tonsillar erythema. Lung examination shows transmitted upper airway noises without wheezing or crackles. Which of the following is the most likely X-ray appearance for the child?
questions.solution: Ans. A. A

Shining light into the patient's right eye causes constriction of her right pupil, but not the left pupil. Shining light into her left eye causes constriction of only her right pupil. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is likely to be found in this patient?

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the office for "noisy breathing”, especially when he is lying on his back. The noise seems to improve when the patient is held upright or during "tummy time." He does not appear to have labored breathing and has never turned blue. Which of the following would confirm the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

Which cell type in the retina is primarily affected in this patient's condition?

questions.text: A 12-month-old girl is brought to the OPD due to 3 days of fever, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion. She has no allergies. Both parents smoke cigarettes and both older siblings received tympanostomy tubes as infants. The temperature is 39.4 C (102.9 F). The patient is irritable but easily consoled by her mother. External ear examination is unremarkable, and external ear canals are patent. Otoscopy findings are shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral antibiotics

 

  • The otoscopic image shows a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane with loss of normal landmarks, which is classic for acute otitis media (AOM).
  • The child also has fever, irritability, rhinorrhea, and congestion consistent with bacterial AOM.

 

Risk factors present in this child:

 

  • Exposure to second-hand smoke (both parents smoke).
  • Positive family history (siblings required tympanostomy tubes).
  • Young age (12 months).

 

These all increase the risk of recurrent and severe AOM.

 

Management:

 

  • First-line treatment: High-dose oral amoxicillin (or amoxicillin-clavulanate in resistant cases).
  • Antibiotics are preferred in this case because:
    • Age <2 years.
    • Fever >39 C (102.9 F).
    • Severe findings (bulging TM).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Supportive care and observation:

 

  • Sometimes appropriate for older children (>2 years), afebrile, with mild unilateral AOM.
  • Not appropriate here because this is a 12-month-old infant with high fever and severe symptoms.

 

Option C. Temporal CT scan:

 

  • Used only for complications of AOM (mastoiditis, brain abscess, cholesteatoma).
  • Not indicated in a straightforward AOM case.

 

Option D. Tympanocentesis and culture:

 

  • Reserved for refractory or recurrent AOM despite multiple antibiotics, or in immunocompromised patients.

choices.text: Occurs after uveitis

questions.text: A student after a heavy lunch from the hostel got ready for his afternoon class. After a while he yawned widely. To his surprise sadly he could not close his mouth. The jaw was stuck. Which of the following statement is not true in the above scenario?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible

questions.text: What test is not used for testing olfaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arnold stick test

 

Tests of olfaction include Smell diskettes, UPSIT (University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test), and CC-SIT (Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test).

 

The Arnold nerve (auricular branch of vagus) stimulation produces cough reflex, not smell sensation, hence Arnold stick test is not used for olfaction.

 

Arnold Stick test: Demonstrate Arnold reflex[ear-cough reflex]

 

  • When the ear canal is stimulated (eg with a cotton swab or stick), some patients develop a reflex cough.
  • This happens because sensory input via Arnolds nerve travels through the vagus medullary cough center efferent vagal output to larynx/trachea cough.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Smell diskettes: Standardized tool to test olfactory function.
 

Option C. UPSIT: Widely used, validated olfactory test.
 

Option D. CC-SIT: Simplified 12-item version of UPSIT for cross-cultural use.

questions.text: A 34 years old male came with pain and watering in the right eye for 36 hours. On examination, a 3x2 cm corneal ulcer is seen with elevated margins, feathery hyphae, finger like projections and minimal hypopyon in cornea. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Aspergillosis

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman comes to the office due to several days of right ear pain. This morning she had 2 episodes of dizziness and almost fell. The patient is currently taking trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for an uncomplicated urinary tract infection. She has had no subjective fever, vision loss, or headaches. Temperature is 37C (98.6F), blood pressure is 116/78 mm Hg, and pulse is 100/min. Ear examination reveals several erythematous vesicles in the right external auditory canal with no drainage. The tympanic membrane is visible and intact. There is mild right-sided facial droop. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Which is the most likely cause of this patient's illness?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Varicella zoster virus

 

This patient has right ear pain, erythematous vesicles in the external auditory canal, dizziness, and ipsilateral facial droop.

 

These findings are classic for Ramsay Hunt syndrome (Herpes zoster oticus):

 

  • Cause: Reactivation of latent Varicella zoster virus in the geniculate ganglion of CN VII.
  • Triad:
    1. Auricular pain + vesicles in ear canal/pinna
    2. Facial paralysis (lower motor neuron type)
    3. Vestibulocochlear symptoms (vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss)

 

So the most likely cause is Varicella zoster virus.

 

 

Vesicle in the auditory canal and auricle of the patient of Ramsay hunt syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas:

 

  • Causes malignant otitis externa (especially in elderly diabetics).
  • Presents with severe ear pain, granulation tissue, sometimes cranial nerve palsies if advanced.
  • But vesicular rash and acute facial droop are not typical.

 

Option B. Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1):

 

  • Causes herpes labialis and occasionally encephalitis.
  • Not associated with vesicles in the ear canal and facial palsy.

 

Option C. Keratosis obturans:

 

  • A benign condition due to accumulation of keratin in the external auditory canal.
  • Causes ear blockage and conductive hearing loss, not vesicles or facial palsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of subcortical dementia?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Pick’s disease

questions.text: Match the incorrect pair:
questions.solution: Ans. C) 3 Epiglottis

Congenital rubella infection

questions.text: A 3000-g female newborn is delivered at term to a 23-year-old primigravid woman. The mother has had no prenatal care. Immunization records are not available. Cardiac examination shows a continuous heart murmur. There are several bluish macules on the skin that do not blanch with pressure. Slit lamp examination is shown. The newborn does not pass auditory screening tests. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Congenital rubella infection

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Super supraglottic swallow

questions.text: Which of the following is not a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Insidious onset of symptoms

questions.text:
Which of these is a true statement? 

 

  1. Ferrys Line - corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of filtering blebs 
  2. Stockers Line - Corneal epithelial iron line at the edge of pterygium 
  3. Hudson-Stahli line - visible all around the base of cone in Keratoconus 
  4. Fleischers ring - Horizontal corneal epithelial iron line at the inferior one third of cornea due to aging
  5. Coats white ring - A form of iron deposit at the level of Bowmans layer of cornea
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 5

 

True Statements:

 

1. Ferrys Line:


A corneal epithelial iron deposition line that forms at the edge of filtering blebs following glaucoma filtering surgery.
It is due to tear film stagnation and iron deposition from tears.
Seen as a fine brownish line adjacent to the surgical bleb.

 

 

2. Stockers Line:


An iron line located at the advancing edge of a pterygium, deposited beneath the corneal epithelium.


Occurs due to tear pooling and chronic irritation caused by the pterygium head.
 

It indicates a slowly progressive pterygium.

 

 

5. Coats White Ring:


Appears as a small, oval or circular superficial white opacity at the level of Bowmans membrane.


It represents iron and fibrous tissue deposition secondary to a healed metallic foreign body injury.


It is a residual, non-progressive lesion and does not affect vision.

 

 

False Statements:

 

3. HudsonSthli Line:
 

A horizontal iron line seen in the lower third of the cornea, usually in elderly individuals.
 

It results from tear pooling near the lower lid margin.
 

It is not associated with keratoconus and is unrelated to the cone base.

 

 

4. Fleischers Ring:


An iron deposition ring surrounding the base of the cone in keratoconus, best seen with cobalt blue light.
 

It forms due to tear stagnation at the cone margin.
 

It is not a horizontal aging line, which differentiates it from HudsonSthli line.

choices.text: Recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies all intrinsic muscles of larynx
Sensory supply to the larynx is by superior laryngeal nerve only
False vocal cord is formed by the lower border of aryepiglottic fold

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement?
questions.solution: Ans. D) False vocal cord is formed by the lower border of aryepiglottic fold

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used for managing a patient with B/L external auditory canal atresia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 

 

 

The device useful in bilateral external auditory canal atresia is the Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) (Image A)

 

Lets analyze each image:

 

Image A Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA):

 

  • Components: sound processor, titanium abutment, titanium fixture.
  • Works via direct bone conduction.
  • Very useful in bilateral external auditory canal atresia or other conductive hearing loss where ear canal and ossicles cannot be used.

 

Image B Cochlear Implant:

 

  • External sound processor and internal electrode array inserted into cochlea.
  • Used for severe to profound bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, not for external canal atresia.

 

Image C Stapes Prosthesis (Piston):

 

  • Used in otosclerosis surgery (stapedotomy).
  • For conductive hearing loss due to stapes fixation, not suitable for canal atresia.

 

Image D TORP (Total Ossicular Replacement Prosthesis):

 

  • Replaces the ossicular chain when absent/damaged.
  • Used for middle ear reconstruction, not in external canal atresia.

questions.text: In Piaget's theory of cognitive development, the concepts of "out of sight, out of mind" and focusing on the "here and now" are characteristic of which developmental stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sensorimotor stage

 

In Piagets theory of cognitive development, the sensorimotor stage is the first stage, spanning from birth to about 2 years of age. During this stage, a child learns to understand the world primarily through sensory experiences and motor interactions with the environment.

 

Key Features of the Sensorimotor Stage:

 

  • "Out of sight, out of mind" This reflects lack of object permanence, meaning the child does not understand that objects continue to exist even when they are not visible. For example, if a toy is hidden under a blanket, the child will not search for it.
  • Focus on the "here and now" The childs thought process is limited to immediate perceptions and actions; there is no abstract or representational thinking yet.
  • Development of object permanence marks the transition to the next stage (around 812 months).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Preoperational stage (27 years): Characterized by symbolic thinking, egocentrism, and animism. Children begin to use language and imagination but lack logical reasoning.

 

Option C. Concrete operational stage (711 years): Children develop logical thinking about concrete objects, understand conservation of mass, number, and volume, and can take others perspectives.

 

Option D. Formal operational stage (12 years): Involves abstract reasoning, hypothetical thinking, and systematic problem-solving.

 

Summary Table

questions.text: A research study is conducted in an urban slum in Mumbai which examined various potential risk factors for breast cancer in a group of 100 women. Based on the image shown below, how many risk factors are statistically significantly associated with breast cancer?
questions.solution: Ans. A) 2

questions.text: 23-year-old comes to the ED with the feeling of food being stuck in the throat. Laryngoscopy reveals fish bone lodged in the left piriform recess. During retrieval of the fish bone, a nerve deep to the mucosa overlying the recess is damaged. Which of the following is most likely to be impaired in this patient as a result of his iatrogenic injury?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Cough reflex

choices.text: Inward deviation of the left eye
Left facial paralysis
Decreased hearing in the left ear

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being hit in the head with a baseball bat. Physical examination shows swelling and bruising around the left temple and eye. A CT scan of the head shows a transverse fracture through the sphenoid bone and blood in the sphenoid sinus. Neurological examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Inward deviation of the left eye

questions.text: A 21-year-old female college student with a history of anxiety is brought to the physician for evaluation of fatigue for the past 6 months. Over the past year, she has had extreme fluctuations in her weight and has become more distant from her friends. She admits to binge eating and induced vomiting. Examination shows poor dentition. This patient is most likely to have which of the follow in serum laboratory profiles?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) pH-7.49, HCO3- 34, Anion gap-9, K-3.0

 

This patient has bulimia nervosa (binge eating with self-induced vomiting, poor dentition due to gastric acid exposure). Repeated vomiting leads to loss of gastric acid (hydrogen and chloride ions) which results in metabolic alkalosis. The kidney compensates by retaining bicarbonate, so HCO3 is elevated. Vomiting also causes loss of potassium in two ways: direct gastric K loss and renal K wasting due to secondary hyperaldosteronism. Therefore, labs show an alkalemic pH, high bicarbonate, normal anion gap, and hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to difficulty hearing for the past few weeks. During the neurologic examination, the physician assesses her hearing using a vibrating tuning fork. The handle of the tuning fork is placed on her left mastoid process until the sound is no longer audible. The tines are then quickly placed near the patient's left auditory meatus, and she reports hearing no sound. When the handle of the vibrating fork is placed on the middle of her forehead, she hears the vibration more strongly in her left ear than her right. This patient is most likely experiencing which of the following types of hearing loss?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Conductive loss in left ear

questions.text:
Identify the correct agent-disease pairings from the list provided:

 

  1. Lyme disease Borrelia burgdorferi
  2. Cat-scratch disease Bartonella henselae
  3. Glanders Burkholderia mallei
  4. Rat bite fever Borrelia recurrentis
  5. Trench fever Bartonella bacilliformis
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

  • Statement 1. Lyme disease Borrelia burgdorferi:
    • Transmitted by Ixodes tick.
    • Characterized by erythema migrans, arthritis, neurologic and cardiac manifestations.
  • Statement 2. Cat-scratch disease Bartonella henselae:
    • Transmitted by cat scratches or bites.
    • Presents with regional lymphadenitis.
  • Statement 3. Glanders Burkholderia mallei:
    • Zoonosis acquired from horses.
    • Rare, but causes pneumonia, septicemia, and cutaneous lesions.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

Statement 4. Rat bite fever Borrelia recurrentis:

 

  • Rat bite fever is caused by:
    • Spirillum minus (Asia, sodoku) OR
    • Streptobacillus moniliformis (USA).
  • Borrelia recurrentis causes Louse-borne relapsing fever, not rat-bite fever.

 

Statement 5. Trench fever Bartonella bacilliformis:

 

  • Trench fever = Bartonella quintana, transmitted by body louse.
  • Bartonella bacilliformis causes Oroya fever (Carrions disease) in South America.

questions.text: A 58-year-old airline captain comes to the OPD after he was found to have abnormal vision testing during a pilot medical certification examination. The patient feels well and has no ocular symptoms. Vision testing shows normal visual acuity but moderate loss of peripheral vision in both eyes. Results of the funduscopic examination are shown in the image below. He is started on latanoprost eyedrops. The medication is most likely to improve this patient's condition through which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Increased outflow of aqueous humor

choices.text: Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus
Aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery
Infarction of the hypothalamus
Compression of stellate ganglion

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because his wife has noticed that his left eye looks smaller than his right. He has had worsening left shoulder and arm pain for 3 months. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Examination shows left-sided ptosis. The pupils are unequal but reactive to light; when measured in dim light, the left pupil is 3 mm and the right pupil is 5 mm. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ophthalmologic symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Compression of stellate ganglion

questions.text: Temperatures used in bithermal caloric test (in degree Celsius):
questions.solution: Ans. A. 30 and 44

choices.text: Superior vena cava

questions.text: An investigator is studying the relationship between fetal blood oxygen saturation and intrauterine growth restriction using MRI studies. The magnetic resonance transverse relaxation time (T2) is inversely related to the concentration of deoxyhemoglobin so that high concentrations of deoxyhemoglobin produce a low signal intensity on T2-weighted MRI. In a normal fetus, the T2 signal is most likely to be the highest in which of the following vessels?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Ductus venosus

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of intense eye redness, watery discharge, and following appearance. Which of the following viruses is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Enterovirus 70

questions.text: Risk factors for primary open-angle glaucoma are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Young age

 

Young age is not a risk factor for POAG; instead, the disease is more commonly seen in older adults.


Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is often asymptomatic and typically affects individuals over a certain age.

 

Other Options:

 

Risk factors include :

 

Option A. Family history of glaucoma: This is a known risk factor, as genetics play a significant role in POAG, with those having family members with glaucoma at higher risk.

 

Option B. High myopia: Individuals with high levels of myopia (nearsightedness) are at increased risk for POAG due to the structural changes in the eye associated with severe myopia.

 

Option C. Hypertension: High blood pressure is also considered a risk factor, as it can affect intraocular pressure and overall vascular health, contributing to the development of glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Young age is not a risk factor for primary open-angle glaucoma, while family history, high myopia, and hypertension are.
